reviewText:

+ Good & Engaging Story
+ Different Ending
+ Different POV in between 3 main char
+ Nice artwork

For all of you who loves VN then it's a must to play, and it is good for all of you who want to start playing the VN genre.

reviewText:
Video Link to my Let's Play #1 (approx 28 min):
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oZ1EcchonO4

About 1.5 hours into the game at the point of this review.. and I will update my review as needed as I get further into this visual novel game.

The game lets you save your progress at any point it seems, I've never had a problem saving or loading anywhere.

It's a fantasy novel of rich magic users and the poor living in rags and how they cross paths into each other.  It isn't a plausible story with all of its sorcery and magic spells, but also seems to be a lot less fantistical then the sort of dragon and giant spider fighting fantasy stories you might expect as well.

So far, the writing seems well done, and the art work is really nice.  I am impressed both visually with the art and the writing so far, about 15% through the game.  (You can check your progress at any point from the main menu)

Considering I am reading this story for my YouTube videos so far, and I am pace for about 10 hours, most people not reading the dialogue aloud will probably read at least twice as fast.  I'd guess this is a 3 to 5 hour game for most people, which will depend greatly on the user naturally with how fast they read or 'skim over' the writing.

Be advised at I just barely got into some pretty mature and very sexual-in-nature content at the 15% mark.  I was kind of surprised by this and the fact that there was no mention anywhere that I saw that this game/novel included sexual or adult content.  No nude art as of yet, but pretty mature sexually natured dialogue, and I can see that it might get much more graphic in the near future.  I will update this as I play through, but BE ADVISED THAT THIS GAME MAY NOT BE SUITABLE FOR CHILDREN/MINORS ESPECIALLY YOUNGER CHILDRED UNDER THE AGE OF 14 OR SO.

So far, I have enjoyed it, so at this early point I will give it a thumbs up with the understanding that I may change this entire review and even my recommendation at any time.  But right now, with the amount of content, the quality of the writing, the entertainment value, and the really nice artwork, I'd give this a thumbs up to anyone who enjoys this kind of game and/or novel.

At this point 15% in, there has been NO choices, and NO gameplay at all.  It's just reading and clicking the screen to move forward.  This is fine for me, as I'm sure choices will be made at some point, but I realize this might upset some people, which is why I have pointed this out.

reviewText:
This is a fantastic game with a fantastic story.
It's a long visual novel, a single playthrough with the non-canon ending was three hours, and it's not like most games (even most visual novels that I've played) in that you make very few decisions. I believe, on my first playthrough, that my first decision didn't take place until about 45 minutes or an hour into the game.

Which brings me to my larger point: this is a game for people who like to read and really enjoy a story. Decisions are fundamental to the game and many of them directly impact which ending you're going to experience, but you won't be choosing little things all the time. You'll be making big decisions, the narrative will be allowing the characters to make the small decisions.

That said, and it's said simply to inform so as to help those who might buy the game to avoid any confusion or frustration with the style of the game, and as I said before: the story is fantastic. There was a great deal of care and consideration put into the writing of this work, there are moral and social quandaries and complexities which are shown to the player and, depending on player choices, the player gets to see the difficult (and not wrong) decisions and opinions formed based entirely on the perspective of the character.

As one character says in the game, in a battle there are no good guys and bad guys. We all go through life convinced that we're right. Those of us who fight do so because we believe we'll get justice. Gilligan suggested that all violence is created by people seeking justice who believe they deserve something which they're being deprived of: be it respect, objects, or any number of other complex social equations. Violence is the attempt to replace feelings of shame and inadequacy with pride and worth. The writing in this game is good enough that it successfully creates multi-faceted characters who always have reasons for whatever violence they might create, and the game creates such a complex social tapestry that it's easy to see how the individuals (on both sides of the conflict) are, in their own way and with their own limited perspectives, right.

reviewText:
I think that it's best to go into this VN blind, that's why I'm putting part of my review in spoiler tags. These aren't really spoilers but rather surprising things.
An Octave Higher is an interesting VN, I could recommend for anybody, mostly because it's not a dating sim, it's not lewd, it's not gory or depressing, nor silly.
It is a branching story about people, music, magic, science, revolution, betrayal and life.
It has multiple main characters, or rather story is told from point of view of several characters, what's unusual for a VN.
There aren't that many choices, but most of those matter. As the story is branching, there are several endings.
A game is accompanied by classical music, what's also somewhat unusual. Music is definitely strong part of An Octave Higher.
It's rather long, takes about 10 hours to finish.
Visual part is weak, though. While backgrounds are nice and detailed, characters are somewhat simplistic and don't go well with those backgrounds, also there is certain lack of variety here.
OTOH writing is not bad, even with some mistakes there and here.
voteText: 28 of 29 people (97%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This was truly a big surprise. I like visual novels despite that a fair amount of them have weak storylines, but this visual novel's story was not weak at all. It was surprisingly well-done and just awesome. Honestly, it could've made a decent storyline for a RPG, but I know indie companies don't always have the money for that.

The point-of-view switches between three different characters. I like this because it allows the reader to see from different story perspectives. It also doesn't cater to one character's biased interpretations of events. After playing through the game a lot, I must say that I think Elise is supposed to be the main character of the three.

The achievements for this game comprise of 5 endings and 1 easter egg. There is also a 6th ending that doesn't yield an achievement (because it's neutral/generic). The easter egg is hilarious, by the way.

The artwork of this game is impressive. Although, sometimes the characters look a bit awkward in how they're drawn.

The music is lovely. Quite lovely. This is to be expected considering the title of the game.

I definitely recommend this game for those who like visual novels! It might also serve to be a good game to introduce someone to visual novels, since it's definitely one of the better ones out there.

reviewText:
An Octave Higher is a visual novel that takes place in the fictional world of Overture where magic exists and a person's place in society depends on if/how they can use magic as well as that person's financial wealth.  Imagine that the setting of this game is similar to the US in the 19th century Industral Revolution except that magic actually exists and you'll get the idea of the premise here.  Basically, you play as three different characters-Frederic, Franz, and Elise-and they are rotated accordingly in the story.  As this is a visual novel, choices do matter.  Depending on the choices you make, you can find yourself aligned with certain characters.  For example, if you play as Franz, you can make decisions that align him closer to Elise or to Aretha, Franz's friend.  Also, decisions regarding whether Franz and Frederic get along determine whether more of the story becomes revealed (and thus, the true path gets told) or it ends.  Although the first half of the story reveals this, the second half reveals it even more-that there is huge class disparity between the aristocracy/bourgeoisie and the proletariat-and magic plays a role in this class division.  That's basically all I will say without revealing more although I will say that the true path is the most tragic so be warned.

There are a total of 6 different endings although one of those endings doesn't show up as a Steam achievement.  The art is beautiful and I especially love the music in this game.  I'm a huge fan of music from the classical and Romanticism eras and the selected pieces fit really well at certain moments.  Of course, there is original music as well and it was equally enjoyable.

Overall, I would highly recommend this game if you're a fan of visual novels and love a good story.  There isn't really any romance in this game but the story is so good that it isn't necessary.  After all, all visual novels don't need to have romance to make them enjoyable.  Also, I'd recommend getting the soundtracks (in DLC format), as I found the music tracks very enjoyable and soothing to listen to.  I'm certainly looking forward to the prequel-One Small Fire at a Time-and hope to be able to play it in the near future.  ^^

reviewText:
Okay this is the first time I reviewed a VN (I did one before with A Kiss for the Petals though that's not a 'proper' review imo) on Steam so bear with me, okay?

I count myself among the minority seeking out for more narrative-driven games and for better narratives within them.  And in this sense, I adore visual novels genre. So, when this gem showed up on my recommendation list, I wasn't expecting much. Maybe some average story, a couple silly characters, that sort of thing. What I got, instead, was a journey to an entirely new and exciting world that left me with a feeling of intrigue and a longing to someday return. A story about how circumstances can divide people.

Set in the city of Overture, a large city in the midst of an industrial revolution spurned by the discovery and implementation of magic, An Octave Higher comprises a nest of concrete and steel itself governed by the marriage of science and magic... that you might even call it magical science. From scientific theory to engineered machines, mana and the powers it provides Overture in its entirety. As you can probably tell, the story revolves around magic, where it is the key to it all: education, industries, to the country’s militia, and is even used in everyday livelihoods for the upper districts and for those who can afford mana potions. Anyone with a mana potion can cast spells, and must do so if they want to live comfortably. Heated water? That calls for fire magic, born from the Courage attribute. Want healing? Summon your Compassion. Omnibuses, the flying taxis of the city, operate on wind and gravity magic (Faith and Willpower).

But magic is far from a catch-all solution if not without costs... It’s borne problems of its own as the city is divided into a three-class system. The Aristocrats on top are the wealthiest, living in their manors and are in charge of most industries of any and all magic machines. The Bourgeois are the middle class where most can afford to use magic and to go to schools that teach the usage of magic. They primarily live in the middle city that takes care of itself. Lastly, the Proles, who make up the poor class that you will usually see in dead-end jobs, are rotting in the shanty towns that make up the lower quarters of Overture. Where the lower class is consistently in awe of the magic and machinery that the rich take for granted, the upper-class look down upon the proles, who grow more and more resentful. Poor citizens are reduced to being compared to simple parts in a machine, and at a certain point in the game we overhear a conversation among factory owners who weigh costs between buying new machinery or hiring more workers.

And this is where we meet our three main protagonists and their respective roles in society. There's Frederic, an aristocrat brat who is pretty much awful to everyone he interacts with despite being a great sorcer player. Soon after, we meet Franz, a well-off student and researcher at the local university. And finally Elise, a young factory worker who lives at a brothel and in a few short months is expected to join the ranks. The narrative jumps around between these three characters liberally and it does effectively convey what everyone is thinking about in any particular situation.

At this point, I can't say enough about the writing. The pacing is excellent, and it encapsulates world building to an almost perfect point. In every instance, the writers find ways to explain details to players. Questions such as: what does the average factory worker's day entail? How does this machine work? What are the rules of the arena sports game, Sorcer? All of these details are provided in context. Another aspect of the game I really loved was the complex theories of magic layered within it. I have no doubt that the game developers spent many hours getting the magic theories down to a science (like its clever use of using magic theories in place of real mathematics), and the end result presented to us definitely allowed me to further immerse myself in the rich fantastical world of Overture. I do wish there was voice-acting in the game though, as that would have definitely aided in the immersion experience.

The music, while a bit lacking in variety, is pleasant and soothing. This gives gameplay a relaxing and calming effect, which in turn causes the hours of playtime to quietly float by. Sound effects within the game have a tendency to fall flat, but they aren't distracting and don't take away from the experience.

Overall, I really enjoyed playing this visual novel and it is undoubtedly one of the better visual novels I've played in recent memory. I grew really fond of the game's setting and characters by the end of the story, and I believe that the game's world still has a lot of potential left to be explored. This visual novel is one that fans of fantasy stories should definitely give a try! And by the way, the developer, Kidalang, already announced a prequel to this game called  A Small Fire at a Time  so make sure to look out for it!

reviewText:
An Octave Higher is a really good story about music, magic, and class conflict set in an interesting steampunk-ish world that reminds me quite a bit of The Legend of the Korra. The story is told from the alternating perspectives of three characters brought together by an unusual research project: Frederic, a narcissistic aristocrat; Franz, a brilliant but asocial student of magic; and Elise, a factory worker who dreams of being a musician.

While the story can be heavy on exposition at times, it's necessary to explain the complex and unique way magic works in the city of Overture in order for the plot to make sense. And aside from a bit of awkwardness when it comes to fitting those details into conversation, the story is really well-written. It's full of original ideas and morally complex characters, and while it's mostly pretty serious and dramatic, it has its moments of comedy as well.

Overall, I really enjoyed it, and I recommend it to anyone else who wants a good visual novel that's not too long. Make sure you don't stop after one ending, as there are several, some of which involve a much longer story than the others. I'd love it if the creators wrote more stories that take place in this world.

reviewText: An Octave Higher is a very refreshing, different kind of visual novel. it looks pretty typical with its steampunk-fantasy setting and magical battle elements, but it doesn't end there at all. It also isn't very romance-focused, despite looking like it will be that way at first. Still, it's neat to see something with a steampunk setting that actually deals with the social and political conflicts of the time. Its handling of the topics is really high-school-level intro to communism
date: but that still gives it stronger themes than most visual novels. Plus, it has some really engaging, well-written characters. If you can deal with it getting a little soapbox-y and the sometimes-cheesy overuse of music references, it's a lot of fun.

reviewText:
Overall this is a fairly decent game. I personally wish that the devs spent more time on the character art (its honestly pretty bad) especially when they've showed off such detailed and interesting backgrounds throughout the game. The devs also beat you over the head with their rules of magic. They make sure to point out at every opportunity that something is powered or created using magic. They go into such depth about random clocks and carriages that it suspends the narrative to circle-jerk over their own created universe. As far as VN's go, An Octave Higher also lacks many of the bells and whistles that other VN's have such as gesture controls, smart skipping and as far as I can tell, branching story lines based on choice.

Now, on the positive side (and please bear in mind that I am only 25% of the way through). The story is good enough for what you pay. You take on the perspective of 3 separate and very different characters. Each one offers an interesting perspective on the brewing class-war, and each offers up their own unique feel and backstory. As far as choice, there hasn't been much, but I believe that the story is fine without it at this point. The world is interesting enough, the conflict (while slow to emerge) is an archetypal classic, and I am truly interested to read more and more into the story to see how life develops for the main characters.

7.5/10 Get it on sale and it's worth every penny.

EDIT: I have now played through the majority of the endings and this game is incredible. There is an entire second act that has to be discovered before you can fully experience the true story of this game. That story is engrossing, gritty and can end a few different ways (Although i personally don't prefer the true ending). I was wrong about the bells and whistles, the game automatically skips all previously read text, pauses at choices whenever they appear and there are a TON of them. The endings are truly different endings, not just 'slightly changed' outcomes (looking at you ME3), and each one is either an 'awe' or 'woah' moment.

After having finished this game through and through (still working towards one missing ending) I have to give this game props as well as upgrade its Llama rating.

8.5/10 Great game all-around and a wonderful story (if you choose the right paths)

reviewText:
An Octave Higher is slightly different from your average Visual Novel, and although not excessive it is quite enjoyable. It is not voiced, which can be seen as a poor point - but I don't think so. No erotic content.

Pros:
+ New mechanics: unlike the traditional Visual Novel you can decide the choices of 3 different characters, giving a new dimension to the tree of choices.
+ Great music - even if the OST is not at the edge of excellence it is written with care and emotion, and the collection of classical music is well chosen.
+ I appreciated the courage to talk about uncomfortable topics like paupery, social balance and so on, not as a mean to differentiate eroge characters but as a central topic.
+ Round characters, with charisma and realism.
+ I know it sounds kind of n00b-ish, but... AFFECTION POINTS DISPLAY! THANK YOU!
+ Presence of easter eggs...

Cons:
- ... that seem to have been added forcefully, sticking out a little too much for my taste.
- The storywriting style is sometimes too innatural: especially lessons and explanations seem to have been written just to provide the reader with some lore background, and their style is poorly matched with the context in which it is put.
- Short, too short. Given the mechanics explained above, it would have been a great deal to have complex tree branching with multiple side-effects, it would have given the story a greater complexity and would result in a more enjoyable game. Maybe next time.

The overall impression is that this game was made on a budget"
recommended: a very good experience! Try it at least when it's on sale!"

reviewText: First of all, this game is awesome. I liked every second of it. The art was great, the music was amazing and the story was so good that I couldn't put it down and finished the game in three sessions over the span of three hours. (I'm a fast reader so it would probably take most people closer to four). I had a few minor qualms in that first, I wish there was more art for the characters that were left out or reused, and more facial expressions. Second, three hours was way too short for me and even though I only finished the story once I wish it was longer and had more content. Other than that beautiful game. 9/10\n\nAlso there were a couple of funny music themed easter eggs throughout the story that I enjoyed.

reviewText:
Overall Opinion: Keep an open-mind while playing and you will enjoy this game.

Likes
-Great stories
-Beautifully crafted setting
-Addresses very real problems in a unique setting
-Interesting characters
-Very few grammatical errors

Dislikes
-Unbelievable character behavior in 'true' ending
-Limited soundtrack
-No voice acting

Meh
-'True' ending will most likely sucker punch you before kissing you sweetly on the cheek
-'Libertad' ending felt like a more believable ending, though content was not as long as 'true' ending
-2/3 main characters are really terrible (in 'true' ending) but otherwise fine

Summary
I don't have a lot of experience with visual novels (VNs), but I found this to be quite compelling. From the lovingly detailed and unique setting to the individual characters who (for the most part) feel very real, everything in this story flows smoothly. The game gives you some limited choices to make that will have a DRASTIC effect on the outcome of the story, so there is some significant player interaction. Otherwise, it's a nice ride. The music is pretty good, but you will hear the same songs repeatedly; that being said, they are not bad songs.

My biggest gripe (if you couldn't tell) was with the so-called 'true' ending. Honestly--and this probably reflects my own personal beliefs--there were times I was literally cringing while playing this ending. Once I got to part 2, everything just fell to pieces...it still flowed superbly and was well-written, but ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ it all if I didn't end up hating 2/3 of the main characters. Which was odd, because in part 1 they were both charming, in their own ways. I feel Elise (probably the biggest POV in part 2) was not true to her character, despite what others may feel, and this made me almost stop playing. A side character from part 1 becomes much more important in part 2 that I immediately liked roughly 5,000 times more than Elise, which is strange, considering their similarities...

Anyways, the 'true' ending still delivers a technically good story, even though I feel like I was dragged through mud on purpose for a good while. If you like a great story and don't mind the lack of voices, this is more than worth the $12.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
An Octave Higher is a gorgeous VN with beautiful artwork, gripping plot, endearing characters, and an enthralling setting. The story takes place in Overture, a city that uses magic for day to day activities. While it seems like a dream, there's a dark side to Overture, the harsh class system which has been stoking the flames for revolution and rebellion. Through the different endings of the game, you can lead a revolution or fight against it. What I loved most about this game is how logical the magic system is. In addition, I found it refreshing to have a visual novel which is not solely focused on winning the girl/guy/bird. There are brief romantic aspects of the story, depending on which ending you want; however they are not the crux or the main focus of the story.  It is tragic, funny and gives you a sense of hope through each of the endings.

Gameplay wise, the UI is very straightforward and there's nothing too difficult about it. I would recommend to try to get each ending  as a way  to fully appreciate the entire experience and the story.
In short, if you are a fan of visual novels or if you simply enjoy a good story, I would definitely recommend this game for you.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Let me just start by saying boy, was I not emotionally equipped to deal with this story.

I had it queued up for a while since I first bought it a few months ago, and I decided to put it on auto-play so I could read it while multitasking. I expected something lighthearted but poop quickly got real after a certain point.

It's a memorable story--it's definitely going to be something I remember and will recommend to people, friends and strangers alike. The dialogue can get pretty hilarious often enough as well.

The only thing I have to point out is there does seem to be a lot of ellipses at certain points--mostly during transitions to another place, starting another day, etc. Perhaps this was part of the plan, since during some of the transitions, a character is traveling so perhaps it was to add to the overall feeling of time passing.

Oh, and the save system is a little wordy. It saves the lines of the last thing you read, but that can get pretty long so a way to just make a save where we could name or have had a screenshot would have been easier. Minor incovenience, but just a little bit of constructive criticism.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game is a visual novel. Just click and read, and repeat, with some liberty of deciding which direction the narrative decides to go.

I thoroughly enjoyed it. I bought this game on the Steam Winter Sale and actually encourage a lot of people to try the novel out. It ties into the wealth inequality that the world is currently attempting to address. And has been addressing since the beginning of civillization itself.
The combat dialogue may seem tedious, but it just ties into the background theme of magic. I rather enjoyed it, as it gave life to the environment of the narrative.

I recommend everyone to just go through the novel at least once. Then use a guide and the fast-forward option to unlock and experience all the endings, and leave the True Ending for last.
Watching each ending was like peeling an onion, a glimpse into each alternate universe. There is no right or wrong answers.

Pros:
-Beautiful Music
-Simple
-Great Story and Theme

Cons:
-Somewhat Predictable
-Cliched?

81/100

reviewText:
[Author has received a review copy of An Octave Higher]

An Octave Higher is one of the newest additions to Steam’s growing library of OELVNs (Original English Language Visual Novels), which I have something of a love hate relationship with. On one hand, getting access to visual novels without having to wait for translation sounds fantastic, but on the other the majority of these new titles lack the funding and quality of story to stand up to their Japanese counterparts. While An Octave Higher is not the OELVN we’ve all been waiting for, it’s most definitely a step in the right direction, boasting a novel and intriguing setting in addition to exploring moral issues that are both interesting and relevant.

Whatever complaints I may have had, I enjoyed my time with An Octave Higher. I loved the setting and the scientific representations of magic, and even cared about the characters by the time the story had reached its end. However, I felt that the routes didn’t conclude in a satisfying way and failed to tie up the various plot threads meaningfully (though the bits before the endings were still enjoyable). The technical aspects, while not impressive, aren’t deal-breaking and have their own charm. All-in-all, An Octave Higher sits on the better side of the fence of available OELVNs and if it sounds like the setting or story would interest you then you should definitely give it a go.

Full review at [https://thegeekclinic.wordpress.com/2015/04/12/visual-novel-review-an-octave-higher/]

reviewText: Charming game. Charming story. I wish there was more choices, and I really think that they should of put more effort into the alternative outcomes. I really liked how even the magic had science, and the characters knew that was illogical. I also liked how the message of the story is debatable depending on what path the reader took. This game made a deep emotional connectin to me; I have never felt so much hatered for a character as I had Fredric. I ♥♥♥♥ing despise Fredric.  Overall great graphics, great music, well written, and an emotional twist at the end. Plus, it's free! So play it!

reviewText:
I've played it to 100% completion, and I must say that this visual novel is marvelous!

An Octave Higher is set in a world where magic is science. In fact, they even have an education major called Magical Science, however contradictory that sounds. The story takes place in Overture, a kingdom where the people are divided into three different classes: Aristocrats, Bourguoises, and Proletariats. You will experience the story from three different perspective, with each character coming from a different class, and therefore has different way of thinking, knowledge, or even belief.

It tells a deeply compelling story about friendship, conflict, betrayal, and hope. It's very hard to point out the good points without spoiling anything, but if you're looking for a non-anime/non-cliche story with high emotional stakes, look no further. An Octave Higher will give you a hell of a ride, one that won't be easily forgotten.

By the way, the game has SIX endings: 1 premature ending, 3 relationship" endings
recommended: and 1 alternate/bad ending. Playism has an official guide in their website
hoursPlayed: and I suggest you get them all. Especially the true ending route
voteText: because only then you'll see the complete story.\n\n10/10 you won't regret your purchase."

reviewText: I wasn't convinced to give this visual novel a try when I looked at its art; it was set apart from generic anime-like drawings, yes, but it was just another unique style of art - it didn't necessarily translate to anything grand. After a while, my curiosity got the better of me and I bought the game on sale, and I don't regret doing so.\n\nHonestly, the best way I can describe it is: Captivating". There's just this finesse in how it was pieced together
date: from the well-written dialogue to the fitting accompaniment to the general story and setting to the overall execution. I wouldn't go so far as to declare this a masterpiece - I could criticize many things about it and nitpick on top of that - but I would definitely say that I liked it and would easily recommend it."

reviewText: 6 hours in and have finished the game" once.\n\nThis is a visual novel
date: if you haven't played one before look it up or you may not enjoy it as its a story with some choose your own adventure elements in it. Not really Otome
recommended: though there are some romantic bits. Any adult content I found so far was some swearing and some "adult discussion" dealing with prostitution / teasing banter between characters
hoursPlayed: \n\nThis is a visual novel with fewer choices than I'm used to but appear to really swing the story (at least in the few places where I played the save before and go back trick).  Three main characters: 2 guys and a girl that the perspective swings between sometimes after some pages
voteText:
other times after a sentence or two. The music is classical and fitting the story. At one point tongue in cheek humor that gave me a chuckle. I enjoyed the style of art with a fair number of CGs and nice background changing all the time. The use of moving and switching images of the characters to indicate a change in point of view was new to me.

This is very well written. One character studies magical scinece and the amount of thought and writing around the theory and logic of magic in this world (see the blackboard images from in game for a quick glance) coupled with the theory of the mage battles for the "sport" sorcerer makes it intellectually capturing and wishing there was a spin-off game letting you use it to wage battles and discover new spells.

For the theme: think Les Misereables meets Harry Potter or more so the Chronicles of Chrestomancy.

I'll be trying the walkthrough next to see some of the true paths over the coming weeks. There does appear to be a skip button so I can fast forward through anything too repetitive. I'll add anything I find different or helpful/not to the review after the next run."

reviewText:
Quite good music, good background art, pretty good character art. The setting is interesting and the writing is intelligent and occasionally quite witty. The story is curious - it starts off being about an unorthodox student project to fix a piano magically, then takes a left turn into bigger things going on in the world, especially in the story routes where one of the protagonists loses his hands and casting ability with them, then organizes the proletariat to rise up and seize the magical means of production. So uh, that escalated a bit, but it's a fun ride.

More details on the writing:
It's witty.
There are some innuendos and a brothel features as a story location, but no real explicit content or fanservice.
There are long stretches without player choice, but there are meaningful choices with direct or indirect consequences.
For a few minutes after the intro there's a sequence that summarizes the setting's magic system, and you do need to at least halfheartedly pay attention to it. It's not that bad.

For a negative, the devs seem to have made their own VN engine, and the controls are unorthodox and take some getting used to. Also sometimes you have to hit advance" three times because there are three lines of nothing but ellipses
date: which is a minor annoyance but not an infrequent one."

reviewText:
This game is rich. Rich in content, rich in great storylines and beautiful artwork and music. A real gem. If you like visual novels, then this game is certainly a good addition to your collection.

There are several endings that this visual novel has and not all of them are easy to reach. But you can still look right decisions up in guides without getting spoilers. You can always save the game to revisit your decisions afterwards.

Other reviews have already written in-depth about the content of the game. I won't repeat what they say here :)

reviewText:
This game is full of creativity from the storyline, to the music and the art, all of which are extremely unique. The art is done in something akin to a steampunk style, and the music is all Classical.

You get to play as three characters through their points of view throughout the game simultaneously. Your interactions between each character you play with each other and the side characters are all specific, meaningful and very well thought-out. Each individual character is essential to the storyline as you progress through the game and each of its endings. Also, none of the characters are perfect. Surprises galore!

I have unlocked all of the endings but it took me 10 hours, which is a pretty solid amount of playing time. This also can depend on how fast you read! If you catch this on sale and you're even mildly interested in it, don't pass the opportunity up!

reviewText:
Note: If you have mental health issues, in particular if you are at risk of suicide, I would advise that you skip this game.

I took about 6 hours to get every ending, as well as the special achievement. I have to say, I thoroughly recommend this game, I enjoyed every second.

Overall, the universe of An Octave Higher is interesting and the characters are engaging. It's a bit of a shame that there's no voice acting and that a lot of the standard VN stuff is missing or changed (Ctrl should fast forward, not F :p), but these are only minor issues in an otherwise amazing game. There are some great moments sprinkled in there - especially when Aretha is around!

Minor spoilers:
The first four endings are pretty lighthearted. In fact, if you only played the game through once you could be forgiven for thinking that An Octave Higher builds up a story in which the core issue is never really tackled. However, you have to make a certain few decisions to unlock the second half of the game. There, it quickly gets dark.
It is for this reason that I advise anyone contemplating suicide to avoid this game, as it deals heavily with this subject matter in the second half. However, if you are stable enough, the final endings are truly amazing.

reviewText:
Disclaimer: review copy received from the developer.

This game has a well-developed setting and a story driven by both the setting and its multi-dimensional characters. It stands on its writing, which is good because it doesn't break the standard visual novel mold. My biggest problem with An Octave Higher is that it goes to a great deal of trouble to teach the player about how magic and magical formulas work, but then never lets the player choose what magic to use. That's not really a big problem, IMO, because it's still a very engrossing 3+ hours.

My full review is at  IndieGames.com. [indiegames.com]

reviewText:
For someone who has a professional writing degree and thoroughly enjoys doing it – writing – and studying I have never been much of a reader. I’m not one hundred percent certain what it is. Obviously I am not illiterate. Clearly there’s a passion there somewhere. But when it comes to reading I’m not as big a reader as what I should be. I’m a much more visual person. I find lengthy texts to be disengaging. Yet to contradict myself I finished half a dozen books last year which isn’t a lot but it was for me. Further yet, quite a number of my favorite texts are lengthy. for example, my favorite book is the 960 page epic Swan Song written by Robert McCammon. Therefore I approached writing about a visual novel with great trepidation.

I fed into my own fears while experiencing An Octave Higher because the constant sense of disengagement when compared to other gaming genres was very real. Yet at simultaneously I could not help myself from being drawn into and immersed in a wonderfully crafted and detailed world. The amount of care and devotion to creating this experience was very evident. Kidalang wove their powerful tale of magic and class like the very best storytellers. It continued to draw me in. The further I read the more I became of its world. The meticulous effort by the team of artists to create powerful imagery to merge with the text was phenomenal. The text itself is extremely well written because it presents a topic that is thought provoking. The issue of class in the real world has always been an important one and there is much to consider from the author’s take on it here.

The only thing that I found lacking in the game was a lack of voice over work. I haven’t spent enough time playing visual novels to have a greater appreciation for the inner workings of the genre but the few other titles that I had played featured voice work. I think this would have given the game that extra layer of immersion that at times it may have needed. However, this is something that I am certain costs a significant amount of money. It is also something that having played other games can make or break a game. If the team was unable to budget for this inclusion to be done properly then it may have been a wise decision not to include this feature. As a result I am not going to be overly critical.

Although I’m not certain that I’ll make visual novels a cornerstone of my gaming experience I can honestly say that if someone were to advise me of a great one that I wouldn’t turn my nose up at them and question where is the gaming. An Octave Higher is a title that I can recommend to people, like myself, who were relatively new to the genre.

For more reviews similar to this one and our daily giveaways please visit http://www.steamified.com/

reviewText: Visual novels have a PR problem. As a genre, they tend to be written off as the least engaging form of gaming, comprised largely of badly-written, trope-laden narratives in step with tired anime convention. There are, of course, many instances where this is not the case, but the reputation exists for a reason. Most of them suck. Finding a solid VN with all the elements of an absorbing and worthwhile game is a tall order, and while Kidalang Studio’s An Octave Higher is far from the perfect experience, it’s just different enough to be worth sinking some time into.\n\nCheck out the full review on  ClickIndie.com [clickindie.com]

reviewText:
Imagine a 19th century setting where industrial revolution was initiated thanks to magic instead of coal/vapor.
Magic is omnipresent,  used in machines and powerful magicians are enrolled in the army/police. The only constraint to use magic is the consumption of mana potions, unfortunately the market is regulated by the state who maintains artificially high prices which means only the richer classes and the corporations are able to acquire them. The only employement possibility for the lower classes is heavy factory work (using magic) where they provided with barely enough mana to work through their shift.

The main part of the story concerns Franz, a student who has been assigned a difficult (if not impossible) thesis project to find practical applications of compassion" magic which is primarily use to heal and give energy to living beings.
Lured by a candidate sponsor in the poorest part of the city
date: he stumbles on a young girl
hoursPlayed: while she was trying to revive a broken piano using compassion magic. Seeing some potential for his thesis
voteText:
he convince her and his mentor to employ her as his assistant... In parallel you'll witness a growing revolution led by a underground group called Libertad which aims to break lower class's dependency to the bourgeoisie for the access to mana potions.


This VN will keep you busy for 8-10h (I'm a fast reader) with a enjoyable story and 5 different endings. They extensively explain the various magic concepts (formulas
votesHelpful:
machines...) and the depiction of magic duels is very dynamic.
The art is pretty and original and the characters have a large set of facial expressions. Special mention for the classical music soundtrack with a very catchy main theme.

Only downside would be the total lack of voices and the relatively shortness. Anyway recommended for any fan of a good fantasy story !"

reviewText: Highly recommended with excellent plot, characters, drawings, and music. The only downside is that the story does feel mostly linear.

reviewText:
******MAY CONTAiN SPOiLERS******

An Octave Higher is an excellent visual novel about magic, friendship, a broken piano, and class war between the proletariat and the bourgeoisie in a capitalist society. It's set in the grand city of Overture, where magic has become a science that's fuelling an industrial revolution, resulting in the mass-scale production of magical machines. Since magic is used to do everything from cooking to driving, being able to afford the necessary mana potions is what separates the upper class from the lower class. Some reviews complain that it's too heavy on lore and explanations, but I really appreciate the detail, which is interesting and provided in context.

The story is told through the alternating perspectives of three main characters: Frederic Godwin, an aristocrat/GIANT D.O.U.C.H.E.B.A.G; Franz Byron, a student/researcher at the Conservatoire; and Elise Shelley, an orphaned factory worker who quickly captures Franz's attention with her special compassion magic abilities. It's supported by a number of minor characters, such as Frederic's overbearing father, Lord Joff Godwin, who founded the Magical Mechanical factory where Elise works; Franz's Professor Johann Poe; Commander Janis Woolf of the Dragoon police unit; Franz's best friend, Aretha Blyton (who is my favourite character because she's smart and funny and likes to bust Franz's balls) and her psychiatrist mother, Alanis; Elise's best friend, Jude; and members of Libertad, a radical proletariat group who are leading the uprising.

The narrative is well-written, the plot is engaging, the art style is beautiful, and the classical soundtrack is fitting. There are a number of decisions that need to be made along the way, and the first path that I followed (which gave me the Egregia ♥♥♥ laude achievement!) led to Franz and Aretha graduating from the Conservatoire with honours (despite Franz's research project not going quite as well as it could have) and the defeat of Libertad by the ruling class. A bunch of other stuff happened as well, but I don't want to give it all away! There are six possible endings, so I'm eager to play through it again, partly because I'm addicted to getting Steam achievements, but mostly because I want to see Franz and Aretha fall in love... and I'm hoping for a revolution ^.^

reviewText: I really enjoyed the experience that this game offers. I bought it on a whim and am very glad that I did. Initially the first thing that struck me about the game was that it was visually gorgeous. The artwork was extremely well done and there was a lot of variety. They do a good job in establishing the world and setting and it really adds to the mood and story. The games story is where it really shines. It tackles some really complex and interesting social problems. It’s really gratifying to see the medium of video games being used in this way. This game is far more than the sum of its parts and when I got the true ending I found myself deeply moved and touched. This game really is an experience and I found myself thinking about it long after I was done playing. I would recommend it to anyone who enjoys a wonderful story. 10/10
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: This is a really well-written visual novel.  All of the magic is explained so that you can understand the battles that take place.  The interactions between the characters feel natural and while there is an anime style, none of the usual cringe worthy moments you'd expect to find in a visual novel are present here.  There are some surprising jokes that pop up now and again though.  The art and music are both excellent.  The game lasts long enough to tell its story, but not so long that you get tired of reading it.\n\nThe one thing I'd like to point out for prospective readers is that the story is sad, though not all of the endings are.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: If an RPG game is what you want, go get Shadows of Mordor. An Octave Higher is not that. An Octave Higher is instead a story to be told, and what influence you have is restricted to choosing what certain characters will say. That doesn't, however, mean that it's a bad game. It's an amazing game, and the magic system is the most logical and amazing I've ever seen. An Octave Higher is simply a tale that goes in different directions depending on your choices, and not a game per se. If that's what you enjoy, consider buying this game for its replay value and amazing story, but if you want action, well, it's not a game for you. I'm sorry. 9/10, only missing a bit more freedom.

reviewText:
I picked up this game because I wanted to see if I'd like the visual novel medium. It was on sale so it seemed like a safe choice.

The game has a good story set in a very captivating world, the characters are unique and memorable, and the choices are simple but meaningful. You experience the story through three character's different perspectives, which is a bit of a theme of the game. It's a good mix of humor, drama, and friendship. It not a tear jerker, but it has its moments.

The art is good, aside from a couple minor things here and there. Though I never really liked steampunk, I really enjoyed the art style. Maybe I never really gave it the chance before.

The music is great and really fits the game's setting.

There are tools for skipping already read dialogue, which is extremely useful for finding the different endings. The text log is very useful too. Saving/loading works perfectly and I never had any technical issues while playing.

Judging by the non-sale price, I was hoping for about 10 hours of entertainment, which I got.

All in all, An Octave Higher is exactly the kind of experience I was looking for. I'd highly recommend it.

reviewText: The story had a little bit too much math involved than I cared for (hated that subject), but luckily, you don't have to actually do any of it. The story was engaging regardless, and I am now aiming to see all other endings. TRIGGER WARNING for some: There is a mild ♥♥♥♥ attempt scene. The characters were likeable, with the exception to one in particular. The music got a little repetitive, but if you're a classical music fan, you will be thrilled by some surprise pieces. Over all, I give this game a yes. I would perhaps wait until it's on sale like I did.

reviewText: The art style is unique and I found that I wanted to keep on going, simply to find out what was going to happen. It wasn’t what I was expecting but I’m really glad that I stuck with it and experienced it. It would have been nice to  have a little bit more input. The game is more of an interative story but not like a telltale game. The options are much more limited but the story is so well done, it keeps you wanting to progress. The game has about 6 different endings. One of the best option, you can fastforward to skip stuff you already read to try different options to get different endings. You will spend countless hours getting all the endings to complete the story.\n\nMy biggest gripe with the game is in it's writing.  The people writing the story apparently don't know the difference between Capitalism, Plutocracy and monopolies. In one of the endings it blames capitalism for the suffering of people but in reality what the story actually describes is a Plutocracy and a monopoly leading to the suffering of people. It does take away from one of the endings.

reviewText:
A compelling story about a broken piano, the lives of three people connected to it, magic, and the social class of a world full of nobility and magic wielders. An Octave Higher is a fun little visual novel in which the choices you make determine the ending you get. Some are good, others bad, but the real ending you gotta work for it.

The music is piano set pieces, a few are from well known artists, and the hand-drawn backgrounds look beautiful and provide an atmosphere to the game. Though I wish they altered them a bit to show the passage of time. The characters might seem two-dimensional at first, but subsequent playthroughs reveal more about them than what meets the eye.

If you want a fun little visual novel to enjoy, I recommend it, especially to people who love the piano.
